channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Supreme Court Asked to Hear Challenge to Trump’s Global Tariffs
item.description: The US Supreme Court was asked for the first time to consider striking down President Donald Trump’s most sweeping tariffs, putting the justices in the middle of a high-stakes fight with worldwide economic implications.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Monday, Oct. 4, 2021. The court's conservative wing offers a menu of opportunities to exploit its 6-3 majority, and give Republicans the type of payoff they envisioned when they pushed through Justice Amy Coney Barrett's Senate confirmation just before the 2020 election.

item.title: G-7 Leaders’ Summit in Canada Continues Without Trump

media:content.media:description: A working session during the G7 Summit in Kananaskis, Alberta, on June 17.

item.title: Sheinbaum Expects to See Trump Soon After Meeting Canceled
item.description: Mexico’s President Claudia Sheinbaum expects to meet Donald Trump soon after their planned encounter was canceled when the US president departed early from a Group of Seven summit in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico's president, departs after casting a ballot at a polling station during the judicial elections in Mexico City, Mexico, on Sunday, June 1, 2025. Mexican voters head to the polls on Sunday to begin picking judges in an unprecedented election that could give President Sheinbaum broad influence over a revamped judiciary, the only branch of government her party doesn't control.

item.title: G-7 Leaders Fail to Convince Trump to Toughen Russia Stance
item.description: A discussion among Group of Seven leaders over dinner on Monday did little to move US President Donald Trump toward tougher sanctions on Russia, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: A working session during the G7 Summit in Kananaskis, Alberta, on June 16.

item.title: Trump Raises Pressure on Iran, Fueling Fears US Will Join Conflict
item.description: Israel and the US are ratcheting up pressure on Iran, sparking fresh speculation that Washington could be preparing to join in the attack launched by its closest Middle East ally.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Stephanie Lai, Arsalan Shahla

item.title: Starmer Says US Not Targeting Steel Ownership in Trade Talks
item.description: The UK does not need to push out British Steel’s Chinese owners in order to cut a deal to reduce US tariffs on steel, Prime Minister Keir Starmer said.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White, Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Emissions from chimneys at the British Steel Ltd. plant in Scunthorpe, UK, on Monday, March, 27, 2023. British Steel has proposed closing its coke ovens in a bid to overcome global economic challenges and build a green and sustainable future, according to an emailed statement.

item.title: Once-Mighty Hezbollah Stays Out of Israel’s War With Backer Iran
item.description: One of Israel’s most feared scenarios has long been that Iran would one day unleash an attack on the country in coordination with its powerful network of allied militant proxies.
item.dc:creator: Dana Khraiche, Youssef Diab

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators wave flags of Hezbollah and Iran during a rally in Tehran, on June 14.

item.title: All the Ways Iran’s Regime Keeps a Tight Grip on Power
item.description: Since the Islamic Revolution in 1979, Iran has been a theocratic republic — and a constant thorn for the countries it marked out as enemies, Israel most of all.
item.dc:creator: Golnar Motevalli

media:content.media:description: Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. Photographer: Atta Kenare/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Bikers With Whips Rout Kenya Anti-Police Protesters; Dozens Hurt
item.description: Hooded motorcyclists armed with whips and clubs attacked crowds protesting alleged police violence in two of Kenya’s biggest cities, in events that left at least 23 people injured.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Protesters throw back tear gas canisters at Kenya anti-riot police as clashes erupt during a demonstration over the death of Kenyan blogger Albert Ojwang, who died in police custody, in downtown Nairobi on June 17, 2025.

item.title: EU Proposes Measures to Cut Red Tape for Defense Investment
item.description: The European Union proposed an array of measures aimed at lightening the regulatory load for defense investments as part of the bloc’s push to boost its arms industry.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: The tail fin of a Eurofighter fighter jet at a defense exhibition in Madrid.

item.title: US Draws Ire of France, Canada at Meeting of Finance Regulators
item.description: Top officials from central banks and finance ministries were forced to call a timeout at a meeting of the world’s most powerful financial watchdog last week, amid clashes over the US stance on climate change.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Marsh, Laura Noonan

media:content.media:description: A resident sprays water on hot spots near a house during a wildfire in Celista, British Columbia.

item.title: EU Proposal to Ban Russian Gas Set for Heated Negotiations
item.description: The European Union’s proposed ban on all Russian gas by the end of 2027 sets the stage for heated debate, with some member states nervous it will boost energy prices and cost companies millions of euros in legal fees.
item.dc:creator: John Ainger, Ewa Krukowska

item.title: Tax Bill Lacks Votes as Senate Aims for Deals on SALT, Medicaid
item.description: Republican leaders are aiming for quick negotiations over needed changes to the newly unveiled Senate tax bill which lacks the votes to secure majorities in both chambers as written.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Alicia Diaz

item.title: Solar Stocks Fall as Senate Bill Ends Key Tax Credits Early
item.description: Shares of US solar companies fell sharply after Senate Republicans released a bill that would end clean energy tax credits earlier than expected, dashing hopes that major cuts passed by the House wouldn’t stick.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Contractors install SunRun solar panels on the roof of a home in San Jose, California, U.S., on Monday, Feb. 7, 2022. California regulators are delaying a vote on a controversial proposal to slash incentives for home solar systems as they consider revamping the measure.

item.title: EU Top Envoy Warns of Larger Conflict If US Involved in Iran
item.description: US military involvement in the spiraling conflict between Iran and Israel risks spreading throughout the Middle East, the European Union’s top diplomat warned on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Max Ramsay, Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: Kaja Kallas in Brussels on June 17.

item.title: Russia Fears for Ally Iran With Few Tools to Influence Crisis
item.description: Russia is watching Israel’s bombardment of Iran with mounting concern for the survival of a key ally, though the Kremlin recognizes it has few levers to influence the escalating conflict in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: Smoke rises following Israeli strikes in Tehran on June 15. Photographer: Khoshiran/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Rich Colleges Would Face Lower Tax Hike Under Senate Bill
item.description: Wealthy US colleges scored a win on Monday with the release of Senate Republicans’ tax bill, which would institute a lower tax increase on endowments than what GOP House members have backed.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Albright

media:content.media:description: The Baker Library of the Harvard Business School on the Harvard University campus in Boston, Massachusetts, US, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. President Donald Trump on Monday threatened to divert billions in grant dollars away from Harvard University and give those funds to trade schools across the US, escalating his clash with the elite institution.

item.title: NYC Mayoral Candidate Mamdani Seeks $70 Billion of Debt to Fund Affordable Housing
item.description: Zohran Mamdani, the democratic socialist polling second in New York’s Democratic mayoral primary, wants to tackle the city’s affordable-housing crisis by taking on tens of billions of dollars of debt.
item.dc:creator: Martin Z Braun

media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/AP Photo/Bloomberg

item.title: Harvard Wins Reprieve, SALT Stalls: Tax Bill Winners and Losers
item.description: US businesses and wealthy universities scored major wins in the Senate Republicans’ version of President Donald Trump’s tax bill, while low-income Americans and clean energy providers are poised to be hit the hardest.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz

media:content.media:description: Dunster House on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts

item.title: Reeves Says UK Won’t Lift Defense Budget Again This Parliament
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves has said any further rise to the UK’s budget for defense won’t come until the next parliament, raising questions about how the government will meet NATO spending commitments.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves meets defense suppliers at RAF Northolt, UK, in March. Photographer: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images

item.title: Putin’s Aide Shoigu in Pyongyang Again on ‘Special Mission’
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin’s top security aide Sergei Shoigu made his third visit to North Korea in as many months according to Tass news service, in a sign of Moscow’s deepening embrace of North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: Sergei Shoigu Photographer: Yasuyoshi Chiba/Getty Images

item.title: Xi Says China Ready to Play Role in Restoring Middle East Peace
item.description: Chinese President Xi Jinping said China is “deeply worried” about the worsening of tensions in the Middle East caused by Israel’s military operation against Iran and urged all related parties to de-escalate as soon as possible.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Qianwei Zhang

media:content.media:description: Smoke rises from the site of a reported Israeli strike on an Iranian state media in Tehran, on June 16. Photographer: MINA/Getty Images

item.title: Crypto Is Investing in Democrats to Advance Agenda in Congress
item.description: Crypto companies are investing in Democrats as they seek to muscle an industry-friendly regulatory regime through Congress and ensure new laws persist after President Donald Trump leaves office.
item.dc:creator: Teresa Xie, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. Senate Republicans intend to propose revised tax and health-care provisions to President Donald Trump's $3 trillion signature economic package this week, shrugging off condemnations of the legislation by Elon Musk as they rush to enact it before July 4.

item.title: Ukraine Arms Supplies Can Stretch Into 2026, Czech Minister Says
item.description: The Czech Republic’s top diplomat said his country is prepared to extend its program to deliver heavy ammunition to Ukraine into next year as Europe rushes to bolster support to Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Krystof Chamonikolas

media:content.media:description: Czech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky in Kyiv in 2024. Photographer: Tetiana Dzhafarova/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Russian Post Resumes Parcel Delivery to North Korea as Ties Grow
item.description: Russia’s postal service is resuming package delivery to North Korea for the first time since 2020 in another sign of deepening ties between the two heavily sanctioned countries.
item.dc:creator: Sofia Sorochinskaia

media:content.media:description: Deliveries from Moscow to Pyongyang will take as many as 15 days.

item.title: Rare Earth Boss Sees ‘Long, Hard Process’ to Loosen China’s Grip
item.description: Western nations will take years to develop enough rare earth processing capacity to limit China’s dominance over the critical ingredients, according to industry veteran and former Molycorp Inc. boss Mark Smith.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Martin Ritchie

media:content.media:description: Molycorp Inc.'s rare earths mining and processing facility in Mountain Pass, California, in 2010. Photographer: Jacob Kepler

item.title: Trump Leaves G-7 Summit Early as Israel-Iran Tension Spikes
item.description: President Donald Trump’s hasty exit from the Group of Seven conference in Canada deepened questions about his promise to bring peace to an increasingly violent world and added fresh evidence of his skepticism toward the institutions that have long underpinned US diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump at the G-7 Summit on June 16.

item.title: Trump Plays Down Iran-Israel Truce as He Leaves G-7 Early
item.description: US President Donald Trump left the Group of Seven leaders meeting in Canada early to deal with the Israel-Iran conflict, playing down the prospects of a ceasefire in favor of “a real end.”
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Stephanie Lai, Arsalan Shahla

item.title: Pakistan’s Army Chief Makes First US Trip After India Clashes
item.description: Pakistan’s military said its army chief is in the US on an official visit, just weeks after President Donald Trump said he had brokered a ceasefire between Islamabad and New Delhi following intense clashes.
item.dc:creator: Kamran Haider, Michal Kubala

media:content.media:description: Asim Munir

item.title: Trump, Ishiba Fail to Reach Trade Deal at G-7 Summit
item.description: US President Donald Trump and Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba failed to reach an agreement on a trade package on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit, an outcome that leaves the Asian nation inching closer to a possible recession as the pain of US tariffs hits its economy.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami, Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba at the Group of Seven (G7) Summit in Kananaskis, Alberta, Canada, on June 16.
